text: The girl, in a WHITE DRESS, leans against the brick wall college building, smoking a rolled cigarette. It is springtime. The green lawns of the college are immaculate. A BUMBLEBEE buzzes on a clover. The girl takes another drag, and exhales a perfect SMOKE CIRCLE. Suddenly, a MAN rides up, on one of those Victorian-era BICYCLES. He’s a stiff, gray-haired professor-type, in a black coat. He nearly topples off his bike when he sees the girl.
(indignant) What’s this?! Women are not allowed on the grounds of the college. And smoking?! The very idea... I’11 put a stop to this. Who are you? The girl looks at him, ironic, unruffled.
I’m nobody. Who are you. The man sputters.

I, young lady, am the prefect. And I‘1l give you one more chance, before I have you dragged from this campus by force. Identify yourself! Who are you?! The girl, slowly, takes another drag. We push in on her f again, as she answers.

I’m Emily Fucking Dickinson. MUSIC. Specifically, Kendrick Lamar, “King Kunta” (2015) This twenty-first century anthem of black empowerment becomes, for now, an anthem of Victorian white-girl empowerment. What, you have a problem with that?
With Kendrick as her underscore, EMILY DICKINSON, 25 year old, struts through the woods of 19th-century Amherst.

“Bitch where you when I was walkin’? / Now I run the game, got the whole world talkin’...” As she walks, and walks, the weeds and brambles whip at t bottom of her dress, getting it dirty. The wind reddens h cheeks. Untidies her hair. KENDRICK (CONT’D) “Everybody wanna cut the legs off him / Black man, take no losses...” She looks exhilarated. But also like she could kill someb

INT. EMILY’S BEDROOM - BEFORE DAWN Four a.m. in the mid-19th century -- dark and quiet as sh Emily wakes up in her small, creaky bed. She throws off t covers. She grabs a shawl, lights a kerosene lamp, and sits down her tiny, cramped writing desk. Takes out a pencil and a scrap of paper. Thinks. Chews her pencil. Then -- she gets into it. Writing. Writing. Lightning striking in her brain. And then -- an interruption. A KNOCK on the door. From outside, her sister’s voice.
Emily! Emily, wake up! Emily crouches, like a tiger, then explodes.
What the fuck! She slams down her pencil, bangs over to the door, opens  4. Her sister, LAVINIA, 22, plump and curvy with a gap betwe her teeth, is standing there, holding a BUCKET.
You have to go fetch water. Emily glares at her.
It is four in the god damn morning, Lavinia. I am writing. Wri-ting.
Mother says you have to go. I did it yesterday.
Why doesn’t Austin do it?
Austin’s a boy, Emily! He doesn’t do chores! Emily shakes her head.
This is such bullshit. Lavinia shrugs, and hands Emily the bucket.
Emily trudges back from the well with her bucket full of water, as the first light of day appears in the sky. She half-whispers, still trying to puzzle out her new poe

(under her breath) “Because I could not stop for Death”... “Because I could not stop for Death”... She thinks up another line, and stops dead in her tracks. Half the water sloshes out of the bucket. She doesn’t car She puts the bucket down. Takes a little pencil and paper of her dress pocket. She scribbles.
“Because I could not stop for Death - He kindly stopped for me.”  Up in a tree, a BIRD chirps. Emily smiles.

An establishing shot of the BIG YELLOW HOUSE where Emily Dickinson spent almost all of her life. A pristine, impos New England mansion, set amongst woods and hayfields. The window up on the right is Emily’s room. This is Main Street, Amherst, 1855 -- not exactly bustlin But still, any action that goes on in the town, the Dickinsons are right in the thick of it. Now, Emily emerges from the path, with her bucket, and en through a SIDE DOOR. INT. KITCHEN —- MORNING Emily’s MOTHER, Mrs. Dickinson (think Laurie Metcalf), an Lavinia are already hard at work in the overheated kitche Mrs. Dickinson tends to a RAGING FIRE on the hearth, whil Lavinia PLUCKS A CHICKEN. As Emily enters, Mrs. Dickinson attacks her.

We needed that water an hour ago! Where have you - oh, Emily, this bucket’s half-empty! You let it all spill out! Oh, you’re a useless girl. Useless! Emily rolls her eyes. This is obviously a familiar routin
Can't we just get a maid? Mrs. Dickinson is appalled.
Over my dead body.
But why? We can afford one.
It’s not for you to say what we can and can’t afford, you wicked thing.
We own six fricking horses, Mom. We can get a maid.

When your father married me, I said he was getting the best housewife in all Hampshire County. No - in all New England! I’d rather scrub the skin off my fingers than hire a maid. And I’m bringing you girls up to be just like me.
But--
(cutting her off) You're going to make a good housewife someday, Emily Dickinson, if it kills me. Mrs. Dickinson claps some flour on her hands, and begins kneading a huge pile of dough.
Now - you need to go get dressed. We have another gentleman coming to see you.
Ooh! A gentleman?!
Mom, no --
He'll be here quite soon. So go upstairs and prepare yourself. This man could very well be your husband.
So romantic!
(dark) I wonder what hideous deformity this one will have.
Don’t be rude. And you better not pull any stunts like you did last time.
I made an offering.
You dropped a dead mouse in that poor man’s lap.
Yes. Like a cat.
You are not a cat, Emily!
No. Tragically, I am a woman. Emily exits, but not before grabbing one of the FRESH SCO her mother has just pulled from the oven.
Those scones are for the suitor! Emily's gone. Mother shakes her head. Lavinia looks annoy
Why don’t I get to have suitors?
I’m not trying to marry you off. You’re good at housework.
So I have to die an old maid because I can fetch water?!

Life isn’t fair, Lavinia. The Dickinson women go back to work. INT. EMILY’S BEDROOM - DAY Emily, in her room, is sneaking another chance to work on poem. She sits at her tiny desk, and scribbles. She hasn’ changed her clothes or brushed her hair or anything. From downstairs, she hears Lavinia screaming.
Emily! He’s here! Frustrated, she slams her pencil down.
Mrs. Dickinson sits in the parlor drinking tea with the suitor, GEORGE. George is gawky, but cute -- a Jesse Eisenberg type. Mrs. Dickinson sips her tea, embarrassed.
She’1ll be down in a moment. I do apologize.

(awkward) Oh - no worries. Now Emily makes her entrance. She has brushed her hair so that it all HANGS IN FRONT OF HER FACE. Like Cousin It. S looks like a woman walking backwards. She looks insane. She walks into the room slowly, her hair blocking her vis
(dramatically) Hello. Mrs. Dickinson gasps.
Emily - cut that out! Emily laughs, and flips her hair back, so she can see. Th she looks at the suitor. She recognizes him.
Oh, for fuck’s sake. George?!
Hey, Emily. Mrs. Dickinson is baffled.
You have already made my daughter’s acquaintance?
Mom, this is George. He’s in the lit club with Austin. We hang out all the time. Mrs. Dickinson’s hand is trembling on her teacup.
Well. I was just telling George here what an excellent wife you will be. How frugal and punctilious you are in all your duties--
Oh, yeah - I’m a real catch. Emily flops down in an armchair and, literally, lights a cigarette. Mrs. Dickinson almost faints.
You put that out right now!
(exhaling) George, can I talk to you for a second? Outside? George leaps up, eager for a chance to be alone with her.
Totally!
Cool. Mom - we’ll be on the porch. Try to relax. Emily heads outside. George follows. Mrs. Dickinson looks at the ceiling, praying for help.
Emily leans against the porch railing, and takes out anot cigarette. George scrambles to light it for her.
What are you even doing here, George?
I just wanted to see you. (Beat.) I always want to see you.
You know I’m not going to marry you, right?
Never say never, Emily. Like you wrote in your poem - “I dwell in Possibility.”  10.
Nice. I love when people quote me.
Why won’t you marry me? I’m not good enough for you?
You don’t understand - I’m not going to marry anyone.
That’s not what your mother says.
I have one purpose on this earth, George - and it is to become a great writer. A husband would put a stop to that.
I wouldn't.
You say that now, but little by little, you would. Emily stubs out her cigarette. George grabs her by the wr
I’m madly in love with you.
Well - too bad.
Is there someone else?
Actually - yes.
Who is he? I’1l kill him.
You can’t kill him. He is Death.
What?  11.
That's right. I’m in love with Death.
A black carriage pulled by white horses rolls up in front the Homestead, in the moonlight. Emily waits for it, at t bottom of the steps.

He takes me out for a carriage ride, every night. He’s a total gentleman. A silver fox. Sexy as hell. The carriage stops, and a HAND reaches out. Emily TAKES T HAND, and climbs in. The carriage rolls away.
George shakes his head, in amazement.
You're such a fucking weirdo. Why am I so attracted to you? Emily smiles at him.
I'd do anything for you.
Well... there is - something - you could do.
Name it. Emily reaches into the pocket of her dress.
You're still editor of the lit mag, right?
Well - co-editor - but yes.  12. Emily pulls out a piece of paper, and hands it to him. He nods.
I want you to publish this.
Whoa! Awesome! You're finally gonna let me publish one of your poems?!
Well - I’ve rewritten it forty times - I’m still not sure it’s ready, but...
This is perfect timing. We have a little space in our newest issue - I can sneak this in. It goes to print tomorrow.
Really?! Tomorrow?!
Okay - but wait.
What is it?
You can’t print my name.
What? Why not? Emily looks over her shoulder. Paranoid.
My father doesn’t approve of women publishing.
Oh, come on. That’s stupid. You’re a genius, Emily - he has to approve of that. A TAPPING on the windowpane interrupts them. Emily looks sees Lavinia inside, waving at her to hurry up and come i
Couldn’t you put my initials or something? Or like - anonymous.  13.
No way. You deserve credit. And you should stand up to your father. Emily’s silent, thinking this over. Then she smiles.
You know what? Fuck it. You’re right. Publish it, with my name and everything. Thank you, George.

(pocketing the poem) Any time, Miss Dickinson. George leans forward, and KISSES Emily on the lips. Then, hops over the porch railing, and takes off, down the lawn Lavinia, through the window, makes a kissy-kissy face at Emily. Emily sticks a finger in her mouth like, gag me.
Emily marches back into the parlor, where her mother and sister are cleaning up.
That was a disaster.
Yes, Emily, you ruined it again.
She didn’t ruin it! They were kissing! I saw!
(scandalized) Kissing?! My god! What is wrong with you?!
You're the one who keeps throwing me at these men!
I’m not throwing you--
Yes you are! It’s humiliating! You'd pawn me off on a widower, a cripple - anyone who would take me! (MORE )

The whole town of Amherst knows how bad you want to get rid of me! At this moment, Emily’s father, EDWARD DICKINSON, appears the doorway. As soon as he enters the room, the energy changes. He’s i charge of this family - a bona fide New England patriarch a top hat and tails. Mr. Dickinson can be tough, even harsh, which is why it w be great if he was played by someone adorable (say, Bob Balaban). He loves his daughter Emily enormously, but the relationship contains much darkness and complexity. Now, he regards his wife and daughters the way a farmer m look at some chickens.
What’s all the fuss?
Mother’s trying to disown me again.
You're twenty-five years old, Emily! I was married at eighteen - it’s high time for you to find a husband!
And move out, you mean!?
Well yes, that is what happens when girls get married!
Why doesn’t anyone care if I get a husband?! Edward puts his hands up, shushing them all.
Emily doesn’t have to marry anyone, as far as I’m concerned.
Thank you, Dad. Jesus - at least somebody around here isn’t trying to kick me out of the family.  15.
(to Edward, annoyed) So you’d just let her stay here, in our house, till kingdom come, doing nothing all day--
I do plenty!
Oh, like what?
I’m the one who found all those bird’s nests. She points.
In the corner, on a table, is a HUGE PILE OF BIRD’S NESTS
(ending the discussion) All right. It’s time for you ladies to clear out, so I can enjoy my pipe and newspaper in peace. He settles into his armchair. Mrs. Dickinson picks up a t
Very well. We should get back to the kitchen, anyway. Girls, come with me.
God, do I have to?!
(staring at her) You have a shitty attitude, young lady.
I just don’t want to do chores twenty-four hours a day.
And what would you do instead? Everybody looks at Emily.  16.
I would just - think. Mrs. Dickinson sighs. Edward lights his pipe, and chuckle
Let her have a break, Mother. It’s all right.
Thanks, Daddy! You’re my hero. She kisses her father on the cheek, and runs out of the r Mrs. Dickinson looks at her husband, coldly.
You just love taking her side, don’t you. Edward shrugs.

You're going to regret it. She’s wild. She doesn’t know how to behave like a proper young lady. And she’ll be the ruin of this family. With that, Mrs. Dickinson exits. Edward puffs on his pipe EXT. GRASSY AREA — DAY Emily lies face-down on a patch of grass, in the sun, sta at a BUMBLEBEE. The bee is fat, and buzzy, ass-deep in a dandelion. A SHADOW falls over Emily, and the bee. She looks up. It’ her older brother, AUSTIN.
What up, sis.

(shading her eyes) Nothin’, bro. Just chillin’. Austin, 28, is tall and handsome (think Benjamin Walker, Anders from Workaholics). Secretly, he’s a bit insecure a his intellect -- especially in comparison to his supremel gifted sister.  17.
Heard you turned down another suitor.
Yeah. Not into it.
Well - on the subject of marriage. I have news. Emily squints up at him.
What news?
I proposed to Sue. And she said yes.
In the back of a hay wagon, Austin is GOING DOWN on his girlfriend, SUE. The wagon jostles violently. Austin’s he is up under Sue’s dress. Sue leans back, eyes closed, in pleasure.
Yes. Yes... Austin emerges from under Sue’s skirt, grinning.
EXT. GRASSY AREA — CONTINUOUS Emily looks like she’s just been slapped.
No. You can’t marry Sue.
Why not?
Austin, she’s my best friend.  18.
Look, Emily, don’t get crazy right now - it’s not a good time. Sue’s sister Mary is dead.
What?! But she was the healthy one.
I know. But then she got typhus and died, like all the others. We have to go to the funeral in an hour.
Jesus. Poor Sue.
Yeah. So just - be respectful of her situation, okay?
You don’t have to tell me to be respectful of my best friend.
Be respectful of the woman who is going to be my wife. Austin turns and walks off. Emily stands there, flooded with rage, as a SONG blasts o Taylor Swift, “Bad Blood.”
“Cause baby now we got bad blood / Hey / Now we got problems...” As the song plays, we see Emily SHRINK DOWN TO THE SIZE O THE BUMBLEBEE.
“And I don’t think we can solve them / You made a really deep cut / And baby now we got bad blood!”
Emily and the BUMBLEBEE sit together on the BRIGHT YELLOW DANDELION, drinking from giant tumblers full of liquor. Emily is WASTED. The BEE is yellow, black, and fuzzy, wit big eyes.  19.
It’s so obvious what’s going on here. Austin knows I love Sue and he’s trying to steal her from me. He’s such an asshole.
(lighting up a joint) Girl, don’t let this relationship shit get in the way of your career.
That's so smart. You’re so right.
Just make dat honey, bitch. Make dat honey. He hands her the joint, and she takes a HUGE HIT.
At the funeral of Sue’s sister Mary. A sizable crowd, including all the Dickinsons, stands around the grave as COFFIN gets lowered into the ground.

(intoning) “O Death, where is thy victory? 0 Death, where is thy sting?” Emily is dressed in white, as always. She looks across th grave and sees SUE, dressed in black. Sue is very, very beautiful -- and very, very sad. She wipes a tear away, and gives Emily a small smile. Emi mouths at Sue: “I love you.” Sue looks down at the grave. The minister wraps up his final prayer and men begin SHOVELING DIRT over the coffin. Emily fights her way through the crowd, trying to get to but just before she reaches her friend’s side, AUSTIN bea her to the punch. He takes Sue by the arm, protectively, leads her off down the hill. Emily stands there, irritated. Funeral guests pass by her all sides, on their way down the hill. Now, Emily looks behind her and sees A STRANGE MAN.  20. The man is tall, with SILVER HAIR, and a GRAY SUIT. He’s attractive, if intense (think Viggo Mortensen). The MAN catches Emily’s eye. He WINKS at her. Just then, LAVINIA appears at her sister’s side. She sees Emily staring into the distance.
Emily - what are you looking at? Emily, rapt, points.
At my friend over there. Lavinia looks where she’s pointing. We see what Lavinia s which is NOTHING.
What do you mean? That tree? We look again, and once again see what Emily sees - the M who is now walking over towards them.
Never mind, Lavinia. The man comes right over to them. He leans in and whisper into Emily's ear.
See you tonight. Emily nods, blushing. The man walks away. Lavinia is confused, but then, she’s used to her sister b weird.
Come on, Emily. Let’s go home. Emily and Lavinia walk together, down the hill.
That was a lovely funeral, don’t you think? Emily shrugs.
Mine will be better.  21. As Emily and Lavinia walk, they pass by a GROUP OF GIRLS, well-dressed and well-coiffed. Emily overhears them, gossiping about her.
Oh my god, it’s Emily Dickinson. The girls all titter.
She's so intense. I seriously cannot handle her. Emily pretends not to have heard them. She lifts her chin proudly and marches down the hill with her sister.
Austin and Sue sit on the very stiff couch. Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson sit across from them, on two very stiff armchai They are all in their funeral clothes. Sue’s face is blea
Well. We are very happy for you. Awkward silence.
I mean - we’re very sorry about your sister, Sue. But we’re very happy you two shall be wed. Austin smiles. Sue, if it is possible, looks even bleaker
So, Austin. What are your plans?
Yes, dear, tell us. Austin takes Sue’s hand.

Well - obviously, nothing is decided yet, but... there is a firm, in Michigan. They have offered me a position. And Sue has a cousin there, so... He trails off. His father stares at him, blankly.  22.
So what.
So - we're thinking of moving to Detroit. Silence.
I’m pretty psyched about it, actually. Edward coughs.
I don’t think so. Austin looks at his father, confused.
You'll join my firm, and stay right here in Amherst.
But - Father, like I just said, I want to go out West...

Nonsense. We can’t have you living so far. This is Amherst. You are a Dickinson. Your grandfather lived here, and his father before that. Right here in this house. Austin stands up in frustration, and paces to the window. Behind him, OUT THE WINDOW, we notice A WICKER BASKET, th is being lowered down BY A STRING. Austin doesn’t see the basket. He’s flipping out at his d
Okay - so what do you expect - that Sue and I will get married and live upstairs?!
Of course not. Don’t be absurd. (beat) You’1l live next door.  23.
Next door?! What - in the Irish shanties?! With the stable boys?

Austin, collect yourself. The lot adjacent has come up for sale. I mean to purchase it. We shall build you a house. Austin gapes at his father. Meanwhile, Sue, from the couch, has noticed the BASKET. S points at it, wordlessly.

The most modern, most elegant of houses. You may oversee the design yourselves. It can be built by fall. Consider it a wedding gift. Austin doesn’t know what to say. He looks at Sue, who is pointing at the window.
What is it, Sue? He turns around, and sees the BASKET. Irritated, he tugs window open, and pulls the basket inside.

The basket. Which holds AN ENVELOPE. Austin pulls the envelope out. It says: “For Sue.” Austin ignores this. He rips the envelope open. Inside is ANOTHER ENVELOPE. It says: “Austin. Do not read this. Give it to Sue.”
Austin, aggravated, hands the envelope over to Sue. Sue takes it, opens it, and pulls out a notecard.
The notecard. Which says, in Emily’s handwriting: “Meet m the woods.”
Sue looks at Austin. He shakes his head. Sue gets up and leaves the room. Austin looks like he wants to punch somebody in the face.
Deep in the woods behind the Dickinson house, Emily stand with her arms folded, looking pissed off. Sue comes walking towards her. The two girls face off.
Is this some kind of fucking joke? Sue says nothing.
You're marrying my brother? Are you insane?
What else was I supposed to do, Emily? My entire family is dead.
I know, and I feel terrible about that, but - Austin?! You don’t even like him! You told me that you don’t respect his intellect. Sue shrugs.
And besides, I thought we were never getting married. I thought we were going to grow up and become great writers together.

That's a stupid promise we made when we were fourteen years old. And even then, I knew it was a lie. I’m not like you, Emily. I didn’t grow up with money. I don’t get to prance around a gorgeous mansion all day and get away with never doing my chores. I don’t have your perfect fucking life.
You think my life is perfect?! Do you even know me?!  25.
I’m all alone in this world. I’m destitute. If I don’t marry Austin, I will literally starve to death.
So you're marrying him for his money. Cool. Very cool.
Spoken like a true fucking rich girl. They glare at each other. Then Emily softens.
I’m sorry about Mary. I really liked her.
Yeah. I liked her too. She was my favorite sister.
Well - since you’re marrying Austin - I guess I’1l be your sister now. They look at each other.
Promise me something, Sue.
What.
Okay, promise me two things. Sue waits.
Number one, that you won’t move away to Michigan. (Beat.) And number two —
Yeah?
That you will always love me more than him. For the first time, we see something like a SMILE glimmer over Sue’s face.  26.
Well. As far as the first one goes - that’s really Austin’s decision. But as far as the second -—
Yeah?

Well, that one’s obvious. I love you so much, Emily. I love you so much, I think I might go to hell for it. A thunderclap. It starts to RAIN. And in the downpour, Em takes Sue into her arms, and KISSES HER. Madly, deeply. The two girls make out furiously in the rain, in the wood Now would be a good time for another great song - maybe something by Lorde? I think you get it.
On the lawn, Austin is playing a game of CROQUET with Geo Emily's suitor. George leans on his MALLET, sipping a glass of SHERRY.
You could have had any girl in town, and you picked Sue Gilbert? Why? Austin lines up a shot, and expertly hits a RED BALL thro a wicket.
I think it’s because she’s the only one who didn’t want me. George laughs, and takes a shot. He misses.
Well - I can relate to that. Your sister is still playing hard to get.
I'm afraid my sister really is hard to get, old chap. In the sense of, hard to comprehend. She’s a freak.  27.
She's a genius.

I'm so sick of people saying that. Austin takes a big whack at a ball. It goes careening off down the slope, and hits a tree. At the same time, EMILY and SUE emerge from the woods. Th are slightly TOUSLED.
Hello, ladies.
What are you doing here, George? Austin takes Sue possessively by the arm.

Sue - I need to talk to you about something. Sue glances at Emily, and then allows herself to be steer away by Austin. Emily and George are left alone. George, trying to be cool, takes out a pair of 19th-centu wire-framed SUNGLASSES and awkwardly slips them on.
Well, babe. It’s done. Emily looks at him, unimpressed.

Your poem. It’s in the Indicator. Right next to a thing I wrote about Percy Shelley. The printers have it - it’1l be out next week. (beat) You're a little bit famous now, Emily Dickinson. He grins at her, expecting to see her smile back. Instead, she looks pale, anxious. She bites her fingernai
Emily? What’s wrong? She shakes her head.  28.
I’m just - scared.
You?! I’ve never seen you scared of anything - you’re absolutely fearless!
I just don’t know how my father will react. George scoffs at this.

Seriously - come on. Your dad is a good guy. I know he’s a little conservative - but he loves you. And he’s smart. He has to know how brilliant you are. And that’s not something he’d want to stand in the way of - is it? Emily looks at George, wanting to believe what he’s sayin Then, from the house, she hears Lavinia, SCREAMING.
Emily! EMILY!!!
Lavinia stands outside the door to the kitchen, wearing a APRON, screaming for her sister.
Emily nods to George.
I gotta go. She hurries off towards the house - but calls back, over shoulder.  29.
Thanks again, George! George leans on his mallet, and watches her go. He sighs.
Pre-dinner CHORES MONTAGE. Fire. Water. Chickens. Emily CUTTING AN ONION, and CRYING.

In the dining room, the whole family sits around the tabl Mother, Father, Emily, Austin, Lavinia, and Sue. The table is laid with beautiful white china, and there’s lots of delicious-looking food. A KITTEN plays at Lavinia’s feet. Edward tears into a piece of chicken.
Wonderful chicken, Mrs. Dickinson. Mrs. Dickinson beams.
It really is delicious, Mother.
Well - thank your sisters. They helped.
One of us did. Emily pinches Lavinia, under the table. Edward clinks on his glass, with a silver knife.
Now, now, listen here. I have a rather exciting announcement. Everyone looks at him, curious.  30.

As you know, in addition to running my successful law practice, as well as maintaining my position as Treasurer of Amherst College, I’ve also served two terms in the Massachusetts House of Representatives. Well - I’ve got my eye on something bigger now. (beat) I have decided to run for Congress. (beat) Of the United States of America. General shock and awe. Mrs. Dickinson looks a bit queasy.
Father - that’s marvelous!
Holy crap, Dad! Lavinia’s KITTEN, under the table, YOWLS.
I appreciate the enthusiasm. Your mother was quite opposed to the idea.
I just don’t want you away from home so much. Candidates are always moving about.
Well, we’ve got to get out the vote, now, haven’t we? The vote, and the message.
What is your message, Mr. Dickinson?
Mine? Well - it’s simple. Let’s keep the country together, that’s what I say. Let’s not be torn apart.
You mean - by slavery.
Father, are you an abolitionist?  31.
Of course not. I don’t care one way or the other about slavery. I just don’t think we ought to go to war about it.
Very sensible, dear.
Personally, I think this Fugitive Slave Act is ridiculous. It’s making us regular citizens into slave-hunting patrols.
You're right about that.
Sometimes I feel like a slave. Everyone looks at her, horrified.
You are a spoiled girl from Amherst, Emily Dickinson. Far from a slave. Emily takes a bite of chicken.
Well, it’s a messy business. But we must preserve the Union, at all costs. That’s my platform. Oh - and bring the railroad to Amherst. That too.
The railroad! Fancy!
Yes, Lavinia, if I’m elected, you shall hear the sound of a train whistle out your bedroom window!
That sounds like a nightmare. Sue giggles.
I see I may have a problem convincing some of my constituency.  32. Austin, now, clinks on his glass.
Well, congratulations, Father. And we have an announcement to make as well. Everyone looks at him.
Sue and I have discussed it - and we will not be moving to Detroit. We're staying here in Amherst - with the family.
Hurray!
Oh, that’s wonderful, darling.
Excellent, excellent! You can hold the firm together, while I’m off running my campaign. Austin nods, uneasy.
Oh, we'll have a big, lovely wedding! We’ll invite all the Dickinson and Norcross cousins - and Sue, of course, your whole family will come--
My whole family is dead. Awkward silence.
Well. (beat) It will still be very nice. Now, suddenly, Emily CLINKS ON HER GLASS.
What is it, Emily?
I also have an announcement. Heads turn to her.  33.
It’s not that big of a deal. I mean, compared to Congress, and getting married, and whatever.
Well, what is it, then? She takes a deep breath.
A poem I wrote - is going to be published. Next week. In the college magazine. Absolute silence. Deafening, hair-raising silence. Silenc that could crush you. Then, Edward speaks - very low, and icy.
I don’t think I heard you correctly. Say that again. The color goes out of Emily’s face.
My poem - will be published.
